ended.note: Recall requested by Government of Mexico on

chief.note: Poinsett left post on January 3, 1830.

ended.note: Recall requested by Government of Mexico on

chief.note: Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on March 12, 1830, after confirmation. Butler did not leave post until after his successor had presented credentials.

ended.note: Mexico severed diplomatic relations with the United States on

chief.note: Shannon left post on May 14, 1845.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on May 29, 1850, after confirmation.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on February 13, 1854, after confirmation.

ended.note: Suspended political relations of the Legation with Government of Mexico on

chief.note: Forsyth left post on October 21, 1858.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on December 12, 1860, after confirmation.

ended.note: Informed Government of Mexico that he considered his mission terminated by note on

chief.note: Commissioned during a recess of the Senate. Otterbourg left post between September 21 and 30, 1867.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on February 14, 1887, after confirmation.
Returned to post on February 14, 1895, but died the same day without resuming charge of the Legation.

Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on December 5, 1895, after confirmation. New letter of credence filed with the Foreign Minister on September 18, 1895, and not formally presented.

ended.note: Promoted to Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary

chief.note: The new government was still unrecognized by the United States when Wilson left Mexico on July 17, 1913.

ended.note: Embassy Mexico City closed at the request of the Mexican authorities on

chief.note: Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on January 10, 1925, after confirmation.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on December 17, 1927, after confirmation.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on December 16, 1930, after confirmation.
Declined appointment.
Did not proceed to post.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on January 20, 1846, after confirmation. Proceeded to post, but did not present credentials; left post about March 21, 1846.
Declined appointment. Commissioned during a recess of the Senate.
Took oath of office and proceeded to Mexico, but did not present credentials.
Not commissioned; nomination twice rejected by the Senate.
This appointment was characterized as a nullity in an opinion of the Acting Attorney General on August 15, 1895.
Not commissioned; nomination not confirmed by the Senate.
Nomination of September 18, 2014, not acted upon by the Senate.
